awd_titl_txt: Understanding the Structure and Dynamics of Solvated Electrons Using Ultrafast Spectroscopy and Quantum Simulation Methods
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms-A Program (CSDM-A) of the Chemistry Division, Professor Benjamin J. Schwartz and his students at the University of California-Los Angeles are using a combination of experimental and theoretical techniques to unravel the structure and behavior of solvated electrons.  Salt water is a common example of an electrolyte, which contains dissolved positively charged cations (sodium, Na+) and negatively anions (chloride, Cl-).  Under certain circumstances, it is possible for electrons (e-) to be dissolved in a liquid.  Such solutions are more difficult to understand and predict, because electrons are thousands of times less massive than atoms and molecules, and are much more mobile.   The Schwartz group is using lasers which produce extremely short pulses of light (30 - 40 quadrillionths of a second) to capture the motions and energies of these fast moving electrons.  The experimental results are being compared with quantum mechanical calculations (quantum mechanics is a type of math that deals with extremely small objects like electrons, atoms, and molecules), and computer simulations of the motions of the liquid molecules that "solvate" the electron. The broader impacts of this work include a better understanding of radiation chemistry (reactions with solvated electrons make high energy radiation dangerous to living organisms) and electron transfer reactions (such as those in both biology and batteries). Because this project combines experiment and theory, undergraduate and graduate student researchers receive a rich experience in experimental chemistry, laser technology, and computer programming, all of which are increasingly valuable for the modern science workforce.  The Schwartz group also works with high school teachers in the Los Angeles area to enrich their science classes through lectures and the development of experimental lesson kits.

The experimental focus of the project uses ultrafast spectroscopy to study the properties of solvated electrons. Ultrafast spectroscopy takes advantages of pulses of light that are extremely short (~tens of femtoseconds), providing a means to "stop the motion" of the electrons on the time scale with which molecules move in room temperature liquids. The theoretical focus of the project is based on mixed quantum/classical simulations. Here, quantum mechanics is used to describe the properties of the solvated electrons, but the solvent molecules are treated classically. The simulations can be used to calculate the results of the ultrafast spectroscopy experiments, so that together, the combination of experiments and simulations can provide new insights into the structure and reactivity of this interesting and important chemical species. Because solvated electrons involve motions of only a single electron, they also provide a test system to compare the predictions of quantum mechanical simulations directly with the results of laboratory experiments.  In addition to the training of undergraduate and graduate students, the Schwartz group also works with high school teachers in the Los Angeles area to enrich their science classes, through lectures and the development of experiment kits.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
When an extra electron is injected into a liquid, the resulting species is termed a ‘hydrated electron’.  Hydrated electrons are important in radiation chemistry:  for example, when ionizing radiation passes into a living organism, the radiation kicks electrons out into the water, and it is reactions of the electrons with the various biological molecules that ultimately produce radiation damage.  Despite their importance in radiation chemistry and other reactions, there are still basic features of the hydrated electron that are unknown, such the structure of the electron in the water, which is in turn connected to the rate of the chemical reactions they perform.  Since hydrated electrons are readily produced in the laboratory and are also amenable to study by computer simulations, they also provide an excellent system for directly confronting theory with experiment.

 

One the experimental side of this project, we used ultrafast spectroscopy to measure various properties of the hydrated electron as a function of temperature.  The experiments allow us to ‘look’ at the electron on time scales of less than one millionth of one millionth of a second  (10–12 s), effectively allowing us to measure the electron’s properties faster than the water molecules can move.  We found that when we injected electrons into a solution containing salt (NaCl), the electrons immediately paired up with Na cations in solution, showing that they are trap-seeking rather than trap-digging (i.e., they do not localize first and then diffuse to find a salt cation later).  The results match well with detailed simulations we did in parallel with the experiments, helping us understand the nature of ion pairing in liquid water.  


On the theoretical side of the project, we continued our exploration of several models of the hydrated electron:  mixed quantum/classical (MQC) models, where the water is treated classical and only the electron is treated quantum mechanically, and ab initio models, where the entire system is treated quantum mechanically via density functional theory (DFT).   Although DFT should be the higher level of theory, what we’ve found is that the fact that the fact that DFT necessitates small system sizes and trajectory lengths, along with charge delocalization error, makes the predictions of this theory farther from experiment than MQC models, particularly those in which the electron resides in a ‘soft’ cavity.  This includes predictions regarding ion pairing of hydrated electrons, the temperature dependence of their absorption spectrum, and their molar solvation volume.   

 

The students and postdoctoral fellows funded by this award are already going on to careers that make excellent use of the fundamental science they learned through this research.  Recent graduate Wil Narvaez, a first-generation college student, is about to start doing postdoctoral work with Ward Thompson at the University of Kansas.  Recent graduate Sanghyun Park is about to start postdoctoral work with Annabella Selloni at Princeton University.  Current graduate students Will Borrelli and Jose Guardado Sandoval, along with undergraduate student Hannah Liu, are developing new skills in computer programming and numerical algorithms, while current experimental postdoctoral fellow Eric Wu and graduate student Stephanie Jimenez are learning advanced laser methods and the safe handling of air-sensitive chemicals.  Both Jose and Stephanie are Latina/o and first-generation college students, so this project has directly contributed to diversity in the sciences.
